message: Our Niagara Falls office has a new location. Visit us at 800 Main Street, Suite 3C, Niagara Falls, NY 14301.

I took to the House floor to stand with the Families of Continental Flight 3407. Members attended today’s confirmation hearing for the Secretary of Transportation, where their presence serves as an urgent reminder that the work to strengthen pilot training and aviation safety is not yet completed.

Honored to have received appointments to the Ways and Means Committee Democrats and the House Budget Committee. Ready to get to work and seize the opportunity to help shape our economy while fighting to bolster the quality of life for Western New Yorkers and all Americans-from the leaders of our next generation, to working families, to our senior citizens.

This week, we recognize civil rights champion Frank Mesiah who recently retired as President of the NAACP Buffalo Branch after 20 years. His activism and advocacy created tangible change in Buffalo and Western New York, including the desegregation of the Buffalo Public Schools. In 1963 he participated in the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, where Martin Luther King, Jr. delivered his “I Have a Dream” speech. As we approach Martin Luther King Jr.’s birthday and take time to reflect on how to continue the push for equality, we look to those like Frank Mesiah for inspiration and honor his legacy.
NA

During the past 8 years, President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama have served our country with dignity and poise. President Obama's historic election in 2008 empowered and encouraged millions of Americans to participate in our democratic process, and his actions throughout his presidency continued to do so. His leadership and legacy will be forever remembered. His vision and determination will inspire for years to come. Through their hard work and humility, the Obamas set an example of what makes America exceptional. As his time as President comes to a close, my most sincere thanks to President Obama. Serving the American people alongside you for the past 8 years has truly been an honor.

Proud to join the French Honorary Consul Pascal Soarès, Diane Benczkowski Cheektowaga Supervisor, Cheektowaga Councilmembers and others to present 93 year old Cheektowaga resident and World War II veteran Corporal Howard Tobin with military service medals from the United States and France, including France's highest recognition, the French Legion of Honor Medal. Born in 1923, Corporal Tobin was raised near Genesee Street and attended Burgard High School before enlisting in the U.S. Army. He was deployed from Fort Niagara and became part of Lieutenant Colonel George Patton’s Third Army. During his service, Corporal Tobin participated in successful efforts to free France, the Battle of the Bulge, and witnessed the liberation of concentration camps in Germany. 74 years after enlisting, Corporal Tobin is honored by two grateful nations for his heroic deeds and bravery.

American companies and workers can compete with anyone on earth, so long as there is a level playing field. Unfair trade policies put American jobs in jeopardy, stifle the growth of our companies, and distort the market. At today’s International Trade Commission hearing, I testified about the Sumitomo (formerly Dunlop) Tire Plant in Tonawanda, where 1,300 employees are United Steelworkers (USW). If these trade policies are corrected, the plant will grow. It’s imperative that we fix unfair trade policies to give our hardworking American men and women an equal chance to succeed in today’s economy.

Work is underway on a $2.8 million project that will restore Scajaquada Creek from Main Street to Elmwood Avenue. The project which includes $1.45 million in funding from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency will remove polluted sediment, resolve flooding issues, and make shoreline improvements. This collaborative effort between the Buffalo Sewer Authority, US Army Corps of Engineers, Buffalo District, Forest Lawn Cemetery Buffalo NY, New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, Buffalo Niagara RIVERKEEPER and Buffalo Olmsted Parks Conservancy is a reminder that we all have an obligation to be good stewards of our environment.

Today, January 27th, is International Holocaust Remembrance Day as designated by the United Nations. The date coincides with the anniversary of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising, to memorialize the victims of the Holocaust. On this day, we remember those lost, reflect on history, and resolve to do everything in our power to prevent such an unspeakable tragedy from ever occurring again.

The story of America is defined by the strength of immigrants overcoming the odds to make a better life for themselves and their families. A wholesale ban on people, based on religion or country of origin, undermines the foundation upon which our nation was built. I stand against this Executive Order, am outraged by its intent and implementation, and will take the concerns of Western New Yorkers with me to Washington, D.C. to join my colleagues who share my disdain in fighting this misguided measure.

Today I took to the House floor to reject this administration’s botched executive order on immigration. Brash and callous actions like this do not adhere the basic American values of which this nation was built. Over the past week, I have heard from so many and have been inspired by citizens and organizations like the International Institute of Buffalo, Jericho Road Community Health Center, Jewish Family Service of Buffalo & Erie County, Catholic Charities of Buffalo, NY and Push Buffalo that are welcoming to immigrants and refugees. I am proud to know our Western New York Community will continue to lead by example and project American values.

As the 8th anniversary of the Flight 3407 tragedy approaches on February 12th, the families met with the Western New York delegation and members of the House of Representatives Transportation and Infrastructure Committee Aviation Subcommittee in Washington, D.C. In the years since the tragedy the families of those lost have become vocal advocates for flight safety reform, winning advances towards “one level of safety” for the flying public. With a new Transportation Secretary recently confirmed, today’s meeting told the story of how we got here and the stressed the importance of preserving new flight safety measures that have helped us go over seven years without a fatal airline crash.

After years of advocacy from the Western New York federal delegation, the new KC-135 tanker mission has arrived at the Niagara Falls Air Reserve Station. The new mission demonstrates the base’s important role in national security and the adaptability and strength of the professionals in the 914th Airlift Wing. The transition to the KC-135 mission helps to protect NFARS from the threat of closure and ensures the base will bolster the local economy for years to come.

As we begin to celebrate Black History Month, today marks a special date in Western New York’s own history, the 100th anniversary of The Historic Colored Musicians Club. The Club was formed in 1917 as a safe space for African-American musicians to play within the then-segregated community. Over the years, legendary jazz musicians like Billie Holiday, Duke Ellington, and Ella Fitzgerald have performed at the corner of Broadway and Michigan. This local treasure unites our community through music and culture, and we wish the Club and its members continued shows and success.
Congratulations to the Buffalo Sled Vets!

The ruling against the President's Executive Order on immigration shows that the ban was not only morally outrageous but also unconstitutional. Our country and community value diversity, and are much stronger thanks to our immigrant and refugee communities. Policymaking by fear and division gets us nowhere. Now, all branches of government can move forward and focus on issues that genuinely create a stronger, safer, and more prosperous country.

“The resignation of President Trump’s National Security Advisor Michael Flynn represents just the latest in a series of actions that raise more questions about the Administration’s ability to handle information and policies of critical consequence to the security of our nation.  “From questionable dealings with Russia, to an Executive Order drafted without adequate counsel from legal and Homeland Security experts, and a very public display of the Administration inability to protect top-level information, Americans are witnessing a dangerous pattern that fails to recognize the serious repercussions of lax judgement in handling highly sensitive material.”

Five young women from Western New York made history this Sunday as their projects were launched into space from NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, Florida. Three Buffalo Public Schools students nicknamed the “Spud Launchers” saw their experiment “Tuber Growth in Microgravity” sent off to the International Space Station, where it will test the ability of potatoes to grow in space. Two other students from Buffalo and Niagara Falls won a design competition to create a mission patch. Through WNY STEM Hub Buffalo-Niagara Spaceflight Project and working together with their teachers and mentors, these impressive public school students remind us of the importance of the arts and sciences, and inspire all of us to reach for the stars.

Over seventy years after serving in the U.S. Army, Mr. George Watts received his long overdue service medals. A Buffalo native and Fosdick-Masten Park High School graduate, Mr. Watts enlisted in the Army at 19. He served in a segregated unit during World War II, meaning his service distinctions were long delayed, until today. As we celebrate Black History Month and remember over 125,000 African-American soldiers who fought in WWII for the freedom of a country that did not extend equal rights and freedoms to them, it is an honor to correct this historical wrong and present Mr. Watts with his service medals.

Just as every child deserves an education, every child deserves to feel safe and comfortable in school. The Trump Administration’s rollback of protections for #transgender students is unconscionable. It hurts our most vulnerable and sends the wrong message to our students and families. Children embrace the beauty and strength in our differences. This directive makes it clear that the Trump Administration does not.

Great to meet engaged constituents at Congress On Your Corner events at Schiller Park Senior Center and North Buffalo Community Center while home from Washington, D.C. this week. We discussed issues ranging from the ACA and Medicare to the EPA and other national topics. Energized to take these concerns with me back to our nation's capitol.

New Markets Tax Credits have helped breathe new life into some of our most historic structures and neighborhoods - greatly contributing to our community's renaissance and spurring $300 million in private investment.  Short term extensions are not enough. It is time that Congress makes this program, which has real impact, permanent.  Browse our interactive map to see the projects New Markets Tax Credits have made possible across Western New York:  http://bit.ly/NMTCWNY

Programs like the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative, Historic Tax Credits, the National Endowment for the Arts, the National Endowment for the Humanities, and National Heritage Areas have fueled Western New York’s renaissance. As we begin to prepare the Fiscal Year 2018 budget, it is crucial that Congress fight for these programs that provide economic opportunities and improve quality of life locally and around the country.

Last night’s address was long on platitudes and warm, deserving tributes to Americans who have overcome great struggles and made incredible sacrifices, but lacked the detailed plans and a thoughtful vision to bring this Country together. Great leaders don’t stoke fear, they inspire confidence and the actions taken by this Administration in recent weeks are invoking genuine concern in my Western New York district and across the country.  Taking away healthcare, building walls, attacking hard-fought civil rights, catering to Wall Street influence, abandoning our allies and allowing for the pollution of air and water – these are not the accomplishments I want for my country or my community.  In the United States of America facts matter, accountability matters, and policies that seek to satisfy the greater good of all people matters. Generations before us toiled to lay the foundation for this good and generous nation. We must not forget the sweat, tears and sacrifices that have contributed to a more perfect union as we continue the fight to do better each and every day.

Proud to submit a resolution designating March as National Multiple Myeloma Awareness Month. Multiple Myeloma is the second most common blood cancer worldwide and most common cancer diagnosis for those over 65. As more become aware of the scourge this and all types of cancer inflict, we can strive to find a cure and support the critical medical research that is the pathway to doing so. (International Myeloma Foundation)

The integrity of our government and democracy cannot be taken lightly. Attorney General Sessions should step down for misleading Congress and the public. I stand with many colleagues on both sides of the aisle to call for the appointment of a special prosecutor to provide impartial and comprehensive answers into potential Russian influence.

As we continue to decide the future of rail in Buffalo, it is Amtrak’s responsibility to provide guidance on their long term plans for service in our community, and advocate in favor of the Buffalo Central Terminal. 319 out of Amtrak’s 510 destinations are better served from the Central Terminal than from Canalside, and it is the only option that can provide service to points West such as Cleveland and Chicago, connecting our great city to many others. Returning rail to the Central Terminal is the best choice for passengers, Amtrak, and Western New York.

There is only one “repeal and replace” strategy that Congress should consider. Repeal this provision that allows insurance companies to claim exorbitant CEO salaries as a federal tax deduction. Replace it with a bill that admonishes insurance companies for these high salaries, and that puts hard-working Americans and seniors first.

This week advocates from across the country will gather in Washington, D.C. for Great Lakes Day. We share grave concerns that the proposed budget for 2018 will include drastic funding cuts to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, including a spellbinding 97% cut to the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative, which has been instrumental to the restoration of the Buffalo River.  Given this threat, it is more important than ever to defend our greatest natural resource. Today I joined Citizens Campaign for the Environment, Buffalo Niagara RIVERKEEPER and Vice Chair of the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence Cities Initiative Mayor Paul Dyster to stand against potential reductions in funding and stand up for the Great Lakes, a critical environmental and economic asset.

“In this debate, you’re either with insurance companies that will make record profits…or you’re with the American people. We have the opportunity to work together to develop a plan that really works for the American people. This proposal is not it.”

The budget blueprint released by the Administration would have devastating consequences for our community and our country. The EPA, National Institutes of Health, National Endowments for the Arts and Humanities, TIGER grants, CDBG funds, and many more crucial programs risk being cut drastically or eliminated completely. We will fight against the destructive and short-sighted provisions in this budget to stand up for Western New York.

Western New York's resurgence is fueled by embracing our unique history. We have a once in a generation opportunity to restore an architectural treasure and inject vitality into a neighborhood. Like & share if you want to see the Buffalo Central Terminal as our next train station. Also show your support by formally submitting public comment to the Buffalo Train Station Selection Committee at: BuffaloRail@City-Buffalo.com
Why I plan to vote NO on the dangerous American Health Care Act that will hurt so many in Western New York.

Since the introduction of the Republican healthcare bill, less than three short weeks ago, people across our district and the country have expressed deep concern for the legislation which was better suited to protect wealthy insurance companies’ profit margins than hard-working Americans.  Today’s defeat of this disastrous legislation, which would have cost both in-terms higher premiums and less coverage, is a victory for children, families, individuals with disabilities and older Americans, but the fight to protect and enhance affordable care continues.  We always said the Affordable Care Act was a start, not a finish.  House Republicans have had seven years to add constructive alternatives to make the Affordable Health Care Act work better.  This bill didn’t come close.  It was rejected by the American people and Congress and we are all better off.

A century ago, the great architects of the world came to build Buffalo. Today’s great architects, in a letter to the Buffalo Train Station Site Selection Committee, came together to advocate for the Buffalo Central Terminal as Western New York’s next train station. The Central Terminal creates a uniquely Buffalonian experience and inspires a distinctly authentic sense of place. By embracing our historic architecture we have an incredible opportunity to invest in our future and inject vitality into the Central Terminal and its surrounding neighborhood.

The American people have a right to know if the President stands to personally gain from proposals he asks Congress to consider. This is why I joined Congressman Bill Pascrell, Jr. and my Ways and Means Committee Democrats colleagues' resolution to request the President's tax returns.

102 year-old World War II U.S. Army veteran Sydney Cole received service medals from the United States and Canada today in a presentation at the Buffalo VA. During World War II, Captain Cole's aircraft was struck by enemy fire during a storm. He made sure his copilot could parachute safely to friendly territory, but in doing so, his own departure from the aircraft was delayed. He landed behind enemy lines where he was shot, captured, and assigned to a POW camp run by Hitler Youth. At one point he only weighed 95 lbs, but served as an example of exemplary conduct while in enemy custody. Captain Cole attended Fosdick-Masten Park High School, now known as City Honors School, but enlisted in the service before graduation. Today he was inducted into the school's hall of fame, and was presented with his high school diploma. Captain Cole's incredible story shows the lasting effect one person can have on the world and reminds us of the bravery and sacrifice of those who fought for our freedoms. http://higgins.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/congressman-higgins-presents-military-service-medals-to-102-year-old

This year’s #LiveNF Volunteer Fair with Niagara University: ReNU Niagara will take place on April 18th. If you’re looking to make a difference in our community, stop by for the opportunity to learn about dozens of groups making an impact. Organizations in search of volunteers are encouraged to register and participate.

The new Republican healthcare proposal gives more power to the insurance companies and less protection for the people who play by the rules. It obliterates protection for patients with pre-existing conditions and eviscerates cost controls. Congress should reject this deceitful plan and stand up for hard-working Americans.
Preservation Buffalo Niagara announces support for the Buffalo Central Terminal as the site of our next train station.

As I have stated in the past, the fight in Syria is not a fight for freedom and democracy; it is a fight for raw power and control between a murderous dictator and violent extremists. Reports of the use of sarin to brutalize the Syrian people by their government is barbaric and inhumane and rightly calls out for condemnation on the world stage. While this targeted strike on the airfield which purportedly administered the chemical attack may be considered proportional, my previous stance on America's role in Syria has not changed. I oppose wholesale American intervention in Syria, and the Congress must debate an authorization of the use of military force.  It should be noted that the Trump administration's about-face on Syrian intervention demonstrates how ill-advised its policy of halting entry of helpless refugees from this war-torn country is.

It’s time for our Annual Congressional Art Competition! High school students can submit original pieces for the chance to win a trip to Washington, D.C. and have their artwork displayed in the Capitol. Deadline for submissions is Tuesday, April 25th at 5pm.

Via Niagara University: ReNU Niagara: The #LiveNF Volunteer Fair is tomorrow - over 30 organizations will be there ready to tell you how you can get involved with the great work that they do! We look forward to seeing you there!

This process needed a little more imagination, a little more vision, and a lot more guts. We’ve lost a generational opportunity to restore the Buffalo Central Terminal and extend Buffalo’s renaissance into its neighborhoods.  We should be capitalizing on our unique architecture and investing in our historic but forgotten neighborhoods.  Instead this is a decision to invest millions of dollars in the status quo – another station almost exactly where Exchange Street sits now, just on the opposite side of the tracks under a highway overpass - not the forward-thinking, bold vision this community deserves.    This decision was not based on what train riders want, what Canalside visitors want or what the people of Western New York want, because they overwhelmingly support the Central Terminal.  In fact, 87.9% of public comments submitted to the train station selection committee favored the Central Terminal. This should have been a decision by Buffalo and for Buffalo.  We don’t take up fights because they are easy, we fight for what’s right.  While I am disappointed by this missed opportunity I remain optimistic about the Central Terminal’s future, and will continue to fight for this historic treasure and the Broadway-Fillmore neighborhood.

Scientific research, environmental protections, and medical innovations create a better, cleaner, and healthier world, while bolstering the economy and creating jobs. Proud to join hundreds of WNYers in Delaware Park to #MarchForScience on Saturday, and to keep up the fight for science in Congress.

As the weather warms up there is a new opportunity to enjoy our waterfront. The Shoreline Trail bicycle & pedestrian bridge and Riverwalk improvements are now complete. The project provides panoramic views along the Niagara River, connects to a scenic overlook near the Peace Bridge, and creates 700 feet of new path along the trail that stretches from Erie Basin Marina into the City of Tonawanda. This $5.2 million investment is part of the larger $60 million Peace Bridge Gateway Project, $15 million of which is federally funded.

A Reuters report recently named Western New York a “hotspot” for lead problems, among thousands of locations across the country. When looking at the proposed budget, instead of talking about a wall, we need to fight potentially devastating cuts to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, and U.S. Department of Transportation in order to take action to combat lead contamination. By failing to address the lead issue through abatement programs and much-needed infrastructure improvements to water and sewer systems, we ultimately fail our children.

In 2005, we fought for and won a $279 million settlement with New York Power Authority to fund the development of Buffalo’s waterfront. As we approach the halfway point of the settlement, it’s critical to take a look at how the funds have been spent thus far and how much remains. We have requested that the data regarding Erie Canal Harbor Development Corporation's expenditures from the settlement be made public. Transparency will prevent more distractions as we strive to make Canalside Buffalo realize its full potential, build on the progress we have made, and move forward with the 2013 Master Plan as quickly as possible.

Voting is now open for the 2017 Congressional Art Competition! View the works submitted by local high school students in our online gallery, and cast your vote for the online competition. Voting is open through May 11th.

If the American Health Care Act becomes law, it would leave the tens of millions of Americans with pre-existing conditions out in the cold. If your child has cancer, your policy would not be required to cover their treatments. Those affected by Alzheimer’s, diabetes, and heart disease would lose their patient protections. This deliberate attempt to deceive the American people and pad the pockets of insurance company executives must be stopped.
NA

The American Health Care Act has heartbreaking consequences for the American people. Hard-working Americans will lose their patient protections. Those with pre-existing conditions will be denied coverage. Essential benefits will be eliminated. The House passed the bill without a CBO score or a thorough understanding of how it will cost and harm constituents. The bill attacks our most vulnerable, and ultimately, puts politics over people.
NA

The suspicious firing of Director Comey continues to raise very serious questions about this Administration’s respect for the rule of law and further underscores the critical need for a full and formal independent investigation into Russian interference. The longstanding tradition of a balance of power and public expectations of truth and transparency at the core of our government is at stake.
NA
We take today to reflect on those who served this nation but never made it home.  Their  bravery and sacrifice will forever be remembered.

For decades, the United States set the world's public policy standard on critical environmental issues. Unfortunately, that tradition ends today.  Today's decision to back away from the Paris Climate Accord, a pledge joined by more than 190 countries to reduce emissions toward the goal of cleaner air and a healthy planet does not demonstrate the leadership that is characteristic of America, nor does it protect the health and safety of people today, or those for generations to come. This is a sad moment in the history of American public policy, and one that thoughtful public officials must commit to reverse.
NA

Buffalo’s renaissance must make its way into neighborhoods. Today we announced a plan to address vacant housing in the Perry neighborhood. We are calling on the Buffalo Municipal Housing Authority to solicit proposals from non-profits and developers to renovate 12 boarded up buildings into new affordable and market-rate housing.

After a horrible attack on members of Congress, staff and Capitol Police, wishing all a full and speedy recovery, including my colleague Congressman Steve Scalise.  I’ve participated in the Congressional hockey games in the past and these fun, good-natured annual sporting events foster bipartisan camaraderie and help raise money for local and national charities.  Our thanks go out to the Capitol Police, who bravely protect members, staff and visitors every day. They saved lives today.
NA
NA

Today the families of Flight 3407 once again came to Capitol Hill to continue their relentless fight to ensure flight safety provisions remain in place. As Congress debates Federal Aviation Administration reauthorization, set to expire in September, some are pushing to roll back the progress we've made since that tragic day in 2009. Between 1990 and 2010, prior to passage of the new flight safety rules, passenger airline accidents led to more than 1,100 fatalities. Since approval of the Airline Safety Act in 2010, there have been no passenger airline deaths in the United States. The safety of the flying public should never be compromised again.
The more we connect the dots the more troubling this looks http://higgins.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/statement-by-congressman-brian-higgins-30

The National Cancer Institute recently awarded Roswell Park Cancer Institute over $2.4 million.  These awards underscore the critical importance of federally funded research and the leadership role local researcher play in providing new hope to people fighting cancer.  http://higgins.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/higgins-announces-more-than-2-million-in-grant-awards-to-roswell-park

New $250,000 federal fire grant comes just in time for North Tonawanda Firefighters in need of replacing over 15 year old SCBA air packs used to safely enter smoke-filled buildings. http://higgins.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/higgins-announces-over-250000-federal-grant-to-the-north-tonawanda-fire

In April Assemblyman Sean M. Ryan and I urged Erie Canal Harbor Development Corporation to move forward on planned development on the former Aud blocks at Canalside.  Today's RFP brings us one step closer to providing additional public amenities and destinations for waterfront visitors.  http://higgins.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/higgins-ryan-applaud-action-on-canalside-s-south-aud-block
The proposed 2018 federal budget threatens the future of Medicare and fails to invest in the growth of the American economy.  Opening remarks during yesterday's Budget Committee markup:

Decades of hard work by both parties to rid our air of toxic pollutants, remove waste from our rivers and lakes, and provide safe drinking water to our communities is at risk.  In Western New York we have seen the EPA’s effectiveness first hand.  Thirty years ago the Buffalo River was declared biologically dead and ecologically destroyed because of the industrial dumping of toxic waste.  Today the River has been remediated and transformed into a recreational waterway with vastly improved water quality.  Cuts to the EPA threaten years of progress.  In the Budget Committee this week I led an amendment that prioritized protecting clean air and water over tax breaks for the wealthy.
Introducing the #MedicareBuyIn and Health Stabilization Act with Rep. John Larson and Rep. Joe Courtney to give people aged 50-64 the opportunity to buy into Medicare.

Over the past several months, a regular barrage of words and actions coming from those entrusted to lead have demonstrated disrespect for women, refugees, transgender servicemembers and others based on race.   We are witnessing a dangerous and dismissive attitude toward some people as less accepted and less valued than others.  This display of intolerance is hurtful to individuals and the noble principles that genuinely make our nation great.   I am proud to call Buffalo -- the ‘City of Good Neighbors’ -- my home.  As a country and as humans we could all benefit from being more neighborly.  Each of us face our own struggles but they are better overcome when we are united rather than divided.  Each of us bring our own strengths as individuals but we are wise to recognize we are significantly stronger together.    Genuine leadership doesn’t embolden hate; instead, it should promote kindness and understanding.  These exhausting distractions tear us apart, preventing us from working together and making real progress. We need less confrontation and more collaboration, fewer outbursts and more outcomes, and less heat and more light.

From the Buffalo River to Tonawanda Coke, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency  has played a critical role in protecting clean air and water right here in Western New York.  Today the future of the EPA is at risk.  Join us next Tuesday to support efforts to "Save the EPA."

As a young boy my siblings and I would join other kids from the neighborhood for countless hours of fun and camaraderie at the Seneca-Babcock Community Center.  With the tremendous support of Dr. Alexander, Mr. Hungerford and others it is great to see plans for this Center to grow to meet the needs of the next generation of neighbors.

The tolls are a physical barrier choking off economic opportunity for Grand Island businesses, driving up emissions that pollute the air in municipalities that are home to some of this community’s greatest natural resources, and creating a daily hassle of backups for residents and all who drive through the town.  Today's announcement that cashless tolls will be implemented at the Grand Island bridges is the result of bipartisan collaboration with local leaders including Nate McMurray—Grand Island Town Supervisor, Senator Chris Jacobs, Assemblyman Angelo Morinello and others who fought with us as well as citizen action led by Brian Michel's WNY for Grand Island Bridge Toll Barrier Removal public campaign.   https://higgins.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/congressman-higgins-applauds-action-on-grand-island-tolls

Wishing WWII veteran Sydney Cole a very happy 103rd birthday!  In March we had the honor of presenting this Prisoner of War with the medals he earned while serving in the United States Army.  Learn more about Captain Cole's incredible story:  https://higgins.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/congressman-higgins-presents-military-service-medals-to-102-year-old

President Trump’s decision to end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program is unjustified, heartless and counterproductive to American ideals as well as efforts to grow the American economy.  This is not a partisan issue, it is a human issue.  Tearing young people away from the only country they call home is cruel and completely unwarranted.  This action continues the Administration’s lack respect for immigrants and lack of focus on issues that can truly help struggling Americans.

Amazon is looking for a home to build a second headquarters.  In a letter to the company CEO, I outline why the Buffalo-Niagara region is a perfect choice: https://higgins.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/in-direct-appeal-to-amazon-ceo-congressman-higgins-touts-the-buffalo

Over the past 48 hours, our office has been inundated with calls, texts, emails and other communications from friends and loved ones of WNYers in the Caribbean Island of Saint Martin who are stranded because of the effects of Hurricane Irma. We need the bureaucratic run-around to stop; the federal government needs to coordinate efforts among agencies and immediately get marshal resources on Saint Martin and other affected Caribbean areas immediately. Read my letter to the President here.

This September 11th, as we reflect on the horrors of 2001 and witness hurricane devastation in communities across the country, we are reminded how our police, firefighters, first responders and Americans respond to any national emergency: with courage.‬
NA

Today, on National Prisoner of War / Missing in Action Recognition day, we are honoring the service of U.S. Army WWII veteran Corporal Frank Garguiolo.  His experience is unthinkable: bravely taking on heavy enemy fire, left the only man standing, captured and fearing for his life, forced into hard labor, starved and neglected, he fought on.  Take the time to read his story and remember the great sacrifices of our POW/MIA servicemembers: https://higgins.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/congressman-higgins-recognizes-former-pow-corporal-frank-louis-garguiolo

ICYMI: Last Friday we joined several other panelists for a discussion about pediatric cancer hosted by AtlanticLIVE. Watch to learn more about the challenges and opportunities from the perspective of families, advocates, researchers and survivors.
NA

Today I spoke at the American Society of Clinical Oncology Advocacy Summit about the need to invest in the limitless potential of science and fight for policies that support the path to better cancer treatments.   https://youtu.be/xpoCgC9hpCc

In the wake of the Las Vegas mass shooting, over 500 people are injured and 59 are dead from the actions of just one madman.  Where is the outrage? Where is the urgency? Where is the action? There is no more time for discord, division, or delay.  American lives are at stake.  We can and must do better.
NA

I have always believed in the necessity of a responsible balance between Second Amendment rights and the critical role of the government to protect Americans.  As we’ve witnessed the growth of unconscionable gun violence in our elementary schools, clubs, on our streets and even at a concert event, we know that lives are at stake with each day that passes.  The fact is that the federal government is not doing nearly enough, and accordingly I have intensified my efforts related to common sense gun reform. While I cannot change the past, I can demonstrate to you – through my actions – that I am listening and fighting. For over five years, I have refused to accept contributions from the NRA, and while I have not chosen to return previous donations, I have instead chosen to donate those funds to local and national organizations fighting for common sense gun safety policies. Moreover, the attached information provides, in greater detail, examples of actions I have taken over the past several years, to address gun safety.   https://higgins.house.gov/sites/higgins.house.gov/files/GUN%20SAFETY.pdf

Attention high school students, parents, teachers & counselors: Join us this Monday, October 16th to learn more about service academy institutions, programs and the application process. Our event starts at 6pm at Williamsville South High School.

As the Western New York community mourns the loss of Officer Craig Lehner, a valued member of the Buffalo Police Department and Staff Sergeant with the United States Army National Guard, we remembered his life and paid tribute to his service on the Floor of the House of Representatives.
Watch as Congressman Dan Kildee and I join a panel to discuss how we can work to give #citiesandtowns the tools to advance community development and economic growth.

Today, the House of Representatives Ways & Means Committee began the process of deliberating the GOP Tax Reform bill.  At the hearing we point out, and the Joint Committee on Taxation Chief confirms, the plan fails to pass the standard advanced by Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, that there would be no tax cuts for the wealthy.  Instead the bill is a major liability to every taxpaying American, but for the Top 1%.

The GOP tax bill bolsters income inequality in America.  Their strategy is to give major tax breaks to corporations with the assumption that more will trickle down to American workers.  That is absurd.

The GOP tax bill gives big breaks to corporate America and assumes by doing that, more money will make its way down to American workers in the form of higher wages.  Earlier this week I argued that we should bypass Corporate America and instead give the tax benefit directly to workers.  And yesterday I introduced an amendment that would have stripped the corporate rate deduction if the $4,000 they promise, will trickle down to American workers, isn’t delivered.

Today our community is excited and fortunate to celebrate the opening of the new Children's Hospital located in the Buffalo Niagara Medical Campus.  This beautiful state-of-the-art facility marks the next chapter in a long history of outstanding doctors and nurses delivering quality pediatric care in Western New York.  Take a look inside!

Construction of the Robert Moses Parkway took away the City of Niagara Falls' most valuable asset - access to arguably the greatest waterfront in the world.  In 2013 we began our fight, on behalf of residents, to take it back.  Next spring deconstruction of the Robert Moses Parkway (Niagara Scenic Parkway) north will begin, and at our request, the New York Power Authority will pay for the $42 million project.  Today we announced a vision for the next step in Niagara Falls waterfront development.  Work along the Robert Moses Parkway south will keep this waterfront momentum going. https://higgins.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/higgins-outlines-next-step-in-niagara-falls-waterfront-development

Two years ago the federally supported Niagara Falls National Heritage Area launched the Discover Niagara Shuttle to connect visitors to over a dozen destinations in the greater-Niagara region.  Today we unveiled a study which confirms the success of the project - a $35 million economic impact in 2016 alone.  With adequate support, the benefits to the local economy in Niagara Falls and beyond are projected to double over the next three years. https://higgins.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/new-report-confirms-the-discover-niagara-shuttle-is-driving-economic

For communities like Western New York our history is also our future.  Federal Historic Tax Credits are creating jobs, generating economic opportunity and playing a role in community revitalization.  The GOP tax bill proposes to cut this effective program.  We are fighting back.

This GOP tax bill provides a heartbreaking catapult to income inequality in America that will serve to grow the gaping wedge between hardworking Americans and wealthy corporate bosses.  This is policy not motivated by bettering the lives of families, students and retirees and certainly not founded in genuine public interest; it is driven by greed and corporate influencers in a callous move to please stockholders and increase the bottom line of big business.   The giveaways provided to those who already have much will be paid for on the broken backs of those struggling to simply get a little ahead in life.  The even greater fear is that this is just the beginning.    The GOP has already indicated plans to move forward on cuts to Medicare, Social Security and Medicaid to pay for this ‘gift.’  These tax cuts will create a manufactured crisis as an excuse to raid the American people of their earned benefits, hurting retirees who worked hard for their Social Security, costing seniors who count on Medicare, and abandoning people with disabilities who rely on Medicaid to stay healthy, independent and in their homes.    I support meaningful tax reform that removes corporate loopholes and advances policies that build stronger families and communities but I cannot support this bill, a cruel American betrayal guised as reform that prioritizes getting anything done before doing real good for the American people and economy.”
